title-group.article-title: Generalizability Analyses of NBDE Part II

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Testing Services, American Dental Association, Chicago, IL, USA
2Psychometrics & Research Services, Assessment & Information Group, Pearson
3Education/Professional Affairs, American Dental Association, Chicago, IL, USA

author-notes.corresp: Tsung-Hsun Tsai, Research and Development/Psychometrics, American Dental Association, 211 E. Chicago Ave, Suite 600, Chicago, IL 60611, USA Email: tsait@ada.org

abstract.p: This research applied generalizability theory to assess the effect of varying the number of cases and items nested within cases on generalizability of scores on Part II of the National Board Dental Examinations (NBDE Part II). In this research, sources of error were defined. Measurement conditions were classified. Error variances and generalizability coefficients for different conditions were computed. The data analyzed were the item responses of 1,535 candidates enrolled in accredited dental education programs who all took the same test form in 2007. Results showed that using more cases of fewer items might lead to a greater increase in generalizability than using more items per case. Other practical considerations such as time and cost constraints must be taken into account when applying the results of this research in other testing situations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: While numerous item formats such as traditional multiple-choice, paired true–false statements, and essay questions requiring examinees to create, organize, and present ideas have been implemented in many testing programs, a testlet format has been utilized to measure complex achievement that requires more than the retention of factual knowledge. A testlet consists of a group of items sharing the same stimulus material, in which the material might be a problem, scenario, graph, chart, map, or story. In order to answer the item correctly, examinees must make appropriate judgments when faced with scenarios requiring the integration of knowledge and skills. Examples of testlets include passages with a series of associated items in a reading comprehension test and clinical cases with a number of items within each case in licensure or certification testing. In a dental licensing examination, a patient case followed by a number of test questions based on the case parallels the application of knowledge to an actual patient’s problem. Therefore, testlets have greater face validity than do stand alone questions.

With an increasing use of testlets in testing programs, one concern of test practitioners is whether the traditional, standard procedures for estimating test score reliability that have been widely used in nontestlet based examinations are still relevant, appropriate, and psychometrically defensible (Sireci, Thissen, & Wainer, 1991; Wainer, 1995; Wainer & Thissen, 1996). Clearly, the traditional test score reliability indices are no longer valid for examinations composed of testlets when all sources of error involved in objects of measurement (in most cases, examinees' observed scores) are considered. In such a circumstance, generalizability theory can be used to untangle multiple sources of error (Brennan, 2001a; Cronbach, Gleser, Nanda, & Rajaratnam, 1972).

Generalizability theory has been widely applied to K–12 statewide assessment programs (Lee & Frisbie, 1999; Li & Brennan, 2007; Wan & Brennan, 2005). Few studies have discussed the framework and its application to high-stakes licensure and credentialing examinations, however. One study used generalizability theory to identify variance components and to optimize the score reliability of a given test composition using data from the Medical Council of Canada examinations. The data analyzed in that study were based on 6,342 graduating medical students. The results showed that the main source of error variance was items within cases and that the optimal strategy for enhancing reliability would be to use cases with 2–3 items per case whereas 1–5 questions per case were actually used (Norman, Bordage, Page, & Keane, 2006). Another study applied generalizability theory to the Canadian Chiropractic Examining Board’s June, 2005, Clinical Skills Examination to determine whether generalizability analysis could yield useful information with regard to sources of variance. The data were collected from 182 candidates, 43 raters, 40 standardized patient actors, and 18 individual cases. The study concluded that “generalizability theory can contribute to the understanding of sources of variance and provide direction for the improvement of individual stations. Generalizability theory, however, must be cautiously applied and it requires careful selection of the floating raters and vigorous training of the raters in each station” (Lawson, 2006).

Compared to the studies described above, this research extends the scope of analysis and discussion by:
adopting an unbalanced design that includes all possible main and interaction effects of the generalizability model,
using a sophisticated and well-designed computer program, urGENOVA (Brennan, 2001a), to estimate parameters, that is, variance components for the unbalanced design; compared with more commonly used programs such as SPSS® or SAS®, urGENOVA is designed in particular for the purpose of conducting generalizability research, and
addressing practical considerations such as time, cost, content, and alternate scoring methods.

This research intends to answer one major question:
Which measurement condition(s) optimize the generalizability of scores on case-based items on Part II of the National Board Dental Examinations NBDE Part II), and how do they do so?
This research aims to provide a practical and useful model to decision makers and test practitioners for determining possible changes in the structure of their examinations for further enhancement of score reliability. This manuscript describes the overall research, including the framework and application of generalizability theory to a high-stakes dental licensure examination. The practical considerations of the potential application of the study results to other licensure testing programs are also discussed in this manuscript.

sec.title: Framework of Generalizability Theory
sec.p: Generalizability theory provides a sophisticated framework to: (a) characterize the facets of measurement, (b) apply an analysis of variance (ANOVA) concept to experimental designs to estimate variance of components associated with facets in G (generalizability) studies, and (c) make a determination in D (decision) studies based on the results from G studies. In D studies, numerous conditions are manipulated. Under different conditions, error variances and reliability-like coefficients, that is, generalizability coefficients, are estimated, examined, and compared. Conditions that produce acceptably precise measurement with regard to error variances and generalizability coefficients are determined.

sec.title: Facets
sec.p: In generalizability theory, sources of error that may affect objects of measurement are referred to as facets. In this research, the universe of admissible observations includes two facets that contribute to the error components in examination scores: cases and items nested within each case. These two facets are considered as random because they are generalized from a small set of cases to a larger set of cases and a small set of items per case to a larger set of items per case.

sec.title: Unbalanced Person-Crossed-With-Items-Nested-Within-Cases Design
sec.p: The two-facet, unbalanced person-crossed-with-items-nested-within-cases p × (i:c) design in this research is associated with three indices—the objects of measurement (p), the number of items (i), and the number of cases (c). In this design, every item (i) is associated with one and only one case (c). Numbers of items per case are not equal, however. Applying the ANOVA concept to this design in this research, the main effects of facets are candidates (p), cases (c), and items nested within cases (i: c), while the interaction-between-facets effects are candidates crossed with cases (pc) and candidates-crossed-with-items-nested-within-cases (pi:c).
There are two types of studies—G studies and D studies—for the unbalanced person-crossed-with-items-nested-within-cases design.

sec.title: G Studies
sec.p: G studies are generalizability studies generalizing specific results from a sample of measurement to a universe of measurement. A universe—a hypothetical population—is defined by facets. In this research, the G study intends to generalize from a small set of cases to a larger set of cases, and from a small set of items to a larger set of items nested within cases.

sec.title: D Studies
sec.p: D studies are decision studies based on the results of G studies. In D studies, numerous measurement conditions for each facet are manipulated. The generalizability and Phi coefficients and the associated error of variances under different conditions are examined. In this research, the D study includes two facets that are characterized in the universe of generalization. The D study is designed to determine whether the generalizability of scores on the case-based items on NBDE Part II would be greater with either more cases with fewer items or fewer cases with more items.

sec.title: Generalizability of Scores and Precision
sec.p: The generalizability coefficient (G-coefficient) and Phi coefficient, derived from generalizability theory are two reliability-like coefficients reported in this research. The G-coefficient, Eρ2, is the ratio of universe score variance to the sum of universe score variance and relative error variance. Relative error variance, σ2(δ), is the error variance associated with using a candidate’s observable deviation score as an estimate of a candidate’s universe deviation score. It is the sum of all variance components that have interactions of objects of measurement with facets in the universe of generalization. The Phi coefficient, Φ, is the ratio of universe score variance to the sum of universe score variance and absolute error variance. Absolute error variance, σ2(Δ), is the error involved in using a candidate’s observed mean score as an estimate of a candidate’s universe score. It is the sum of all variance components associated with facets in the universe of generalization without the universe score variance. Both G and Phi coefficients have a range of 0–1.

While both coefficients and the associated error variances are reported, the Phi coefficient and the absolute error variance are more important than the G coefficient and the relative error variance in this research because NBDE Part II is used for making decisions about candidates for licensure purposes. Candidates' levels of achievement on NBDE Part II are classified into: (a) “pass” if the candidates' scores are at or above the established pass/fail score, and (b) “fail” if the candidates' scores are below the established pass/fail score. The pass/fail score is set through standard setting activities. Comments from Webb and Shavelson when they overviewed generalizability theory (2005) support the use of the Phi coefficient on licensure, criterion-referenced examinations when critiquing score reliability of the examinations.

sec.title: Instrument
sec.p: NBDE Part II is designed to assist state boards in determining the qualifications of individuals who seek licensure to practice dentistry. The examination is typically taken by student candidates during the last year of dental school. It assesses the ability to understand important information from biomedical science, clinical dental science, behavioral science, and patient management, and the ability to apply such information in a problem-solving context. This comprehensive, computer-based examination consists of 500 multiple choice items. Items derived from different disciplines are intermingled throughout the examination. Items are presented with a stem pairing a question or statement with a list of four or five possible responses. The examination includes 400 discipline-based items and 100 items based on 8–10 case problems. A case consists of a synopsis of a patient’s health and social histories, radiographs, and photographs. A series of test items is associated with each case. Candidates must have the requisite knowledge and skills to answer the items correctly.

sec.title: Sources of Data
sec.p: The data used to assess score generalizability were comprised of the individual item responses of 1,535 candidates who were enrolled at the time in accredited dental education programs and all took the same examination form of the NBDE Part II in 2007. The traditional method of scoring multiple choice items in which every item is scored as “1” for a correct response or “0” for an incorrect response and there is no penalty for skipping items or guessing was used.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p:
Random effects variance components for the G study unbalanced p × (i: c) design with np = 1,535 candidates, nc = 8 cases with ni = 10–16 items per case were estimated by urGENOVA (Brennan, 2001b). The estimated G study variance components from urGENOVA were used as inputs to GENOVA (Crick & Brennan, 1983) to obtain D study results. In the D study p × (i: c) design, candidates respond to each of the n c′ cases with
n i ′
items nested within each case. In this research, the total number of case-based items for each candidate to respond to is 100. The D study included 10 different conditions with combinations of
n c ′
n i ′
and
n c ′
so that
n c ′
≤ 100 and
n i ′
n c ′
≤ 100, and combinations of
n i ′
and
n c ′

n c ′
≤ 5 and

n c ′
≤ 100. The D Study with 10 conditions is presented in Table 1 .

caption.p: D Study for p × (i: c) Design

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A summary of descriptive statistics—including raw score mean, raw score standard deviation, mean difficulty in percentage (mean percent), and a traditional reliability coefficient, KR20, for 100 case-based items—is presented in Table 2 . Descriptive statistics for the 400 case-independent items and for the entire 500 items are also presented. Additionally, the traditional reliability coefficient, KR20, measuring internal consistency, is reported as a standard indicator of the score reliability since all items in this examination are dichotomously scored. As shown, for the entire examination with 500 items, the raw score mean is 336.26; the raw score standard deviation is 36.92; the mean percentage is 67.25; and the score reliability is .9362. For the case-independent section with 400 items, the raw score mean is 274.16; the raw score standard deviation is 31.94; the mean percentage is 68.54; and the score reliability is .9320. With regard to the case-based section with 100 items, the raw score mean is 62.10; the raw score standard deviation is 6.92; the mean percentage is 62.10; and the score reliability is .6341.

Some observations regarding candidate performance on discipline-based and case-based items include (a) the average percentage of case-based items answered correctly by the study sample is lower than the average percentage of discipline-based items answered correctly by the same study sample, that is, 62.10% versus 68.54% and (2) score reliability of the case-based section is low (r = .6341) because of the relatively small number of items compared with the number of items in the discipline-based section, that is, 100 items versus 400 items.

The G study results for the unbalanced p × (i:c) design are presented in Table 3 . As shown, error variance components of the main effects of candidates (p) and cases (c), and error variance component of the interaction effect. (pc) are relatively small, that is, .00302, .00579, .00014, compared with error variance of the main effect of items nested within cases (i:c), that is, .05284 and error variance of the interaction effect of candidates-items-nested-within-cases (pi:c), that is, .17486. Clearly, items nested within cases (i:c) and candidates-items-nested-within-cases (pi:c) are two major sources of error that affected the examination scores.

caption.p: G Study Results for Unbalanced p × (i:c) Design

sec.p: The D study results for the p × (i:c) design based on the G study estimated variance components from Table 3 are reported in Table 4 . An investigator might examine Conditions I through VI to determine whether score reliability can be improved by increasing the number of cases with a lesser number of items per case. As shown, both reliability coefficients are maximized with G coefficient (.63312) and Phi coefficient (.56382), and error variances are minimized with relative error variance (.00175) and absolute error variance (.00234) if the examination contains 100 cases with 1 item per case. However, reliability coefficients for 20 cases with 5 items per case, 25 cases with 4 items per case, and 50 cases with 2 items per case are insignificantly smaller than those for 100 cases with 1 item per case, and error variances for those conditions are insignificantly larger than those for 100 cases with 1 item per case.

caption.p: D Study for the p × (i:c) Design

sec.p: Given the largest variance component on i:c effect as shown in Table 3, an investigator might also examine Conditions VII through X to determine whether score reliability can be improved by increasing the number of items per case. As shown, 5 cases with 20 items per case maximize G coefficient (.62961) and Phi coefficient (.46583), and minimize relative error variance (.00178) and absolute error variance (.00346). Reliability coefficients for four cases with 25 items per case are not much smaller than those for five cases with 20 items, and error variances for four cases with 25 items are not much larger than those for five cases with 20 items.

The D study results, under the restriction that
n i ′
n c ′
≤ 100, show that increasing the number of cases improves the score reliability, while increasing the number of items per case does not do so.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Overall, the results from the G and D studies show that using more cases might lead to a greater increase in score reliability than using more items per case, and generalizability can be further enhanced by including at least 10 cases.

To cross-validate the results, they were replicated using data from a different form of the examination and the same unbalanced design for generalizability analyses. The sample was comprised of 961 student candidates then enrolled in U.S. accredited dental education programs taking a different test form of NBDE Part II in 2007. Results from generalizability analyses concluded that using more patient cases might lead to a greater increase in score reliability than using more items per case, and generalizability can be enhanced by using at least 10 cases.

Some observations on this research follow. First, as shown in Table 3, the G study results found that variance due to items nested within cases was the largest component while variance due to candidates was the smallest component. The findings from this G study were similar to the findings of a study using data from the examinations of the Medical Council of Canada (Normal et. al. 2006). One possible method to reduce variance due to items nested within cases is to identify the items that are not strongly correlated with their corresponding cases either through the judgments of content experts or through poor item statistics such as low point biserial correlations. Once those items are identified, they would be removed from generalizability analyses. It is anticipated that variance due to items nested within cases would be reduced, and therefore, score reliability is expected to be further improved. Second, while both G and Phi coefficients for all conditions are reported, the G coefficients are very similar across all conditions and are approximately equal to KR20 for the case-based items (Table 2). The comments from Webb and Shavelson regarding their overview of generalizability theory (2005) suggest that the absolute decision should be focused when designing G and D studies for a criterion-referenced examination. In light of their comments, the decision makers might want to focus on the impact of test design decisions on the Phi coefficient in this research because NBDE Part II is a licensure, criterion-referenced examination. For example, the decision makers might want to examine the Phi coefficients instead of the G coefficients for all conditions in Table 4. As shown, a Phi coefficient is .49 under the current test design (eight cases with 12 items). Using the Phi coefficient under the current test design as a baseline judgment, the decision makers would find that a Phi coefficient is reduced to .45 (8% reduction) if the number of cases is reduced to 4 while a Phi coefficient is increased to .54 (10% increase) if the number of cases is increased to 20. This useful information helps the decision makers to make a decision when designing a licensure, criterion-referenced examination. Third, the identified facets were simplifications of the real examination, and some potential sources of error were not considered in generalizability analyses. For NBDE Part II, “disciplines” might be a potential source of error that contributes to generalizability in addition to patient cases and items nested within cases because items in different disciplines are intermingled throughout the examination. Fourth, assuming that the total number of case-based items on NBDE Part II is held constant at 100 items, utilizing a larger number of cases as opposed to smaller number of cases would likely result in candidates taking longer to complete the examination. Depending on the amount of time allowed to complete the examination, this change might have the effect of turning the examination into a speed test as opposed to a power test. Policy makers would need to consider the appropriateness of such a change in the nature of the examination. Finally, this research might be designed to allow investigators to explore and evaluate the alternative methods of scoring cases as units on generalizability.

This research provides a psychometrically sound and practical model with framework, procedures, and application to those decision makers and/or test practitioners who might consider possible changes in the structure of examinations for further improvement of generalizability. For the use and application of the results of this research to other licensure testing programs, decision makers or test practitioners might wish to consider the following practical implications: (a) the possibility and/or challenge of obtaining a sufficient number of additional cases, (b) the impact on testing time as well as candidates' testing experience if the number of cases and/or items per case is increased, and (c) the issue of content representation—typically, a broader coverage of content, that is, more cases, might improve the psychometric properties of the examination as compared to increasing the number of items within cases.
